node.text: How do unrealistic expectations harm our relationships? Join the exploration on @sexwithemily’s podcast as I talk about exercises that help develop an embodied sense of sexuality, as well as my new game.

node.text:
As I travel this week, I was inspired by a beautiful @TED Talk from @taiye.entirely that encourages us to ask not where you are from but where you are local, and that resonated with me. Where we're from can be quite a limiting descriptor, whereas where we are local tells a fascinating story about where we feel at home, with whom we form our relationships, what rituals and cultural customs we hold dear and what restrictions dictate how we move through these places. 

Through the lens of this last year, we may have been "at home" but perhaps we didn't feel at home, as we were disconnected from the experiences that make a place feel familiar and resonant. So, I'm curious, not where you're from, but where do you feel local? 
To listen to Taiye's exploration of this topic, visit the link in my bio.

node.text:
I’m hearing a lot about burnout lately, from friends, clients and colleagues. It seems that many of us are in need of a break right now. 

As I take a moment of vacation, I am reminding myself (and all of you) that a break is freedom from any “must do”. It’s not a chance to do all the things I’ve been neglecting but an opportunity to just be, releasing the need to produce and optimize, and instead allowing life to happen around me. By relinquishing agency, I can truly relax.

node.text:
We’re asking ourselves many questions right now as we rediscover how we relate to one another. Should we gather? Is it safe? And once we’re together, what can we ask? What can we tell? So much has happened in the last 18 months, that we long to deepen our conversations past the surface. 

For more on reconnection, listen to my conversation with @jayshetty on his podcast On Purpose.

It's not a permanent state of enthusiasm. Love is something that you actively cultivate.

Listen to my conversation with @jayshetty on this week's episode of On Purpose wherever you get your podcasts.

node.text:
This couple came to talk about the deep conflict and the secrets that they both carry surrounding their work. One person can't talk about what she does and one person can't talk about the fact that he no longer wants to do what he does.

Season 2 of #HowsWorkPodcast is now available on all platforms.

🎧 Listen to If I Quit, What Will People Say? on Spotify or wherever you get your podcasts.

For show notes and transcripts, visit estherperel.com/podcast

node.text:
This is the story of #WhereShouldWeBegin, the game. 

The pandemic left us missing intimacy and play, so I created a game to help us rediscover both. Designed for partners, dates, or friends, Where Should We Begin? is many games at once. I have played it with my team, my family, and my oldest friends. And each time we have discovered something new about each other.

To preorder the game, visit estherperel.com/thegame or click the link in my profile bio.

For the time being, we are only shipping to the United States. We will ship internationally in the future — stay tuned.

node.text:
@rachelbotsman defines trust as “a confident engagement with the unknown.”

In relationships, trust isn’t a promise to never hurt each other. It’s the risk that we will hurt each other and the confidence that, if we do, we will come together to heal. We will support one another. We will be kind. We will have each others’ backs. And it’s not just something that happens because we’ve decided to be together, or to move in, or to say “I do.”

Cultivating that level of trust requires millions of micro-risks that show us we’re not foolish for being confident in our relationship. It requires taking risks together that show us our partner isn’t the same as the people from our past who hurt us. Most importantly, trust requires taking risks together that help us grow into better partners for each other.

Here are five small micro-risks to help build trust in your relationships:

Go outside and say hello to the strangers you pass.
Compliment someone on something specific.
Call your friend who’s been feeling blue and leave voicemails even if know they won’t respond.
Tell your partner you’re taking them on a date even if you know they’d rather watch TV.
Tell your partner something about yourself that they don’t know. (This is one of my favorite exercises in therapy.)

This clip is an excerpt from this week's #LettersFromEsther workshop: Risk-Taking and Trust. To watch the full video, visit my YouTube channel: YouTube.com/estherperel/live

node.text:
On May 20th, we will begin #7DaysForPlay. Sign up to receive daily small, sensual, playful exercises to help you practice slowing down and connecting to your erotic self.

Register for this free challenge at bitly.com/7daysforplay or by clicking the link in my profile bio.

If you know someone who may wish to join us, send them this video or tag them in the comments below.

(There is a version for people who are in a relationship and for those who are solo. I suggest choosing the option that corresponds to your relationship status, even if you won't be doing this with your partner.)

node.text:
Foreplay doesn’t need to be something that diminishes as we get older, it’s an energy that deepens as we grow. Foreplay is for play.

On the subject of anticipation, something playful is coming soon. Join me for my upcoming free audio series, The Art of Foreplay: bitly.com/7daysforplay.

#7DaysForPlay

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
I frequently explain how in modern culture, we turn to one person, our partner, to provide what an entire village once did: a sense of grounding, meaning, and continuity. But we shouldn’t forget the importance of the village: how we build it and how we maintain it.

Friendships have carried me through so many things, including love and loss. They've sheltered me from many storms and remain a part of my life that I enjoy expanding and nurturing. So this season on my podcast, “Where Should We Begin,” we will pursue new conversations about friendship. 

If you are interested in being on the podcast, please let us know. These conversations could involve someone you have lost touch with, the friend you wish would forgive you, or the one you wish to let go of. If you are feeling stuck and think a session with me could help you two and you are interested in being on the podcast please tell me your story follow the link in my bio or apply here: https://whereshouldwebegin.estherperel.com/apply

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says '" Seduction is a way to explore each others' worlds histories, fantasies, and desires and that type of play is an education in itself. Esther Perel'.

node.text:
Seduction is a way to explore each others' worlds, histories, fantasies, and desires—and that type of play is an education unto itself. 

In the early stages of dating, we hope to discover more about the other person through intense emotional and physical connection. This relies on play. True seduction is a slow process, but it is accelerated by the feeling of newness between two people. Newness brings excitement and room for mystery—and that mystery allows for play. 

In our blog “Dating Advice for Turning a Spark into a Flame,” we discuss tools for making a first date successful, including the art of seduction. Follow the link in my bio!

node.text:
From @greatness with @lewishowes.

There’s a pervasive myth in today’s world about the significance of self. In our increasingly more individualistic society, we obsess over the lexicon of the “self” - self-love, self-care, self-help, the selfie, etc. We are encouraged over and over again to focus attention on ourselves, to shape and perfect and clarify the boundaries of this independent identity before focusing on our relationships with others, and certainly before finding the relationship. 

But, we don’t just learn to love ourselves by ourselves. It’s a process of loving others and allowing ourselves to be loved that shows us who we are, what we need to work on, and how to better love and accept ourselves in our flaws and limitations. In one of my favorite newsletters, I explore this concept deeper with a personal story of self-love that included a whole host of people outside myself. Follow the link in my bio to to read.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on August 31, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
One of my favorite things I’ve created in the last 5 years is the Rekindling Desire course because it’s an encapsulation of so much of my work and accessible to so many people. It introduces a way of thinking about life that not only helps rekindle desire in our relationships but also gives permission to think of ourselves as multi-faceted, dynamic, erotic beings—focusing on aliveness and vitality over productivity or output. This, in turn, encourages us to approach our partners with fluidity, curiosity, and wonder. 

With Rekindling Desire, I wanted to give people a place to start. By addressing self-consciousness, fear, and complacency, this program will give you the tools to explore your desires and become more open and intentional with your needs. Explore through the link in my bio, and let me know what you think. How do you rekindle desire and the erotic in your life?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on August 30, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text:
Earlier this month, I asked you all "what does being single mean to you?" and I got a whole host of amazing answers. I read them all, fascinated by how differently we each approach this word and how deep some of your answers explored the topic. The most common responses were that single means either loneliness or freedom, and while they seem to be juxtaposing, of course, the two are interconnected. 

We tend to think of being single as a matter of being alone rather than a matter of choosing the types of relationships we want to be in—including the relationship we have with ourselves. While the state of being single sometimes includes loneliness, it also includes freedom and independence, perhaps by the same person on different days. I have a dear friend who's traveling the world by himself right now, and while he feels the ultimate autonomy to move through the world, he often also feels quite lonely at times. His experience is blended, perhaps like many of yours. There is room for both qualities, even in a single human experience. 

So, as we end the month, I'm curious - how would you like to change the definition of the word single? What should it be updated to mean or include? To read more of this month's newsletter, visit the link in my bio or visit estherperel.com/blog

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on August 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says '" In relationships, trust isn't a promise to never hurt each other. It's the risk that we will hurt each other and the confidence that, if we do, we will come together to heal Esther Perel'.

node.text:
Life is a game of risk. From the moment we come into this world to the moment we die, our survival instinct acts as a silent captain navigating every situation we face or desire.

Trust is the confidence that even if the water is freezing and something bites our toe, we’ll be okay. And if it ends up better than we could have expected, we’ll always remember that day at the lake where we held hands and plunged into the reinvigorating waters together. 

In relationships, trust isn’t a promise to never hurt each other. It’s the risk that we will hurt each other and the confidence that, if we do, we will come together to heal. We will support one another. We will be kind. We will have each others’ backs. And it’s not just something that happens because we’ve decided to be together, or to move in, or to say “I do.” Cultivating that level of trust requires millions of micro-risks that show us we’re not foolish for being confident in our relationship.

Taking risks is vital in relationships, giving our partners the opportunity to build or repair trust - without these risks, we will never know whether we can truly trust the other person. How do you bring intentional risk taking into your relationships? Click the link in our bio to learn more about this practice or visit estherperel.com/blog

node.text:
There’s no one-size-fits-all approach to successful relationships. With so many factors at play and qualities that make each individual and thus their relationships unique, there are many ways to do it well. At the end of the day, a balance of autonomy and belonging are key ingredients in a successful, compatible connection. 

Listen to my conversation with @drmarkhyman on The Doctor’s Farmacy to talk about modern relationships, pitfalls and recipes for success. Find the full episode through the link in my bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on August 23, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, bicycle and outdoors.

node.text:
As I return from vacation and integrate back into "real life" in New York, I'm thinking about what I want to bring back from my time away. The answer might surprise you: I'm working on saying no more often. 
 
My natural inclination is to say yes to everything I can, to give of my time and expertise, to offer mentorship, support, and at least a phone call. My practice was built on the generosity of my mentors, so it's important to me to give back often. However, as I come off 2 weeks of holiday, I'm struck by the importance of creating space in my life, accepting the loss that comes with making choices, knowing that every yes must also be balanced with a no. Saying yes to space and silence, to reading a book, or to taking a leisurely a walk means saying no to a phone call or a meeting — and that's okay. My time in Provence taught me the value of idleness and how much can be savored and enjoyed when there's nothing on the agenda. That's what I will bring back with me. And I will need to trust that the people in my life will understand and respect this choice. Now, more than ever, creating designated space to be rather than to do is vital to our mental and emotional health. 
 
In my @ted Talk earlier this year with @helen_walters, we discuss the value of routines, rituals, and boundaries for alleviating stress and creating space for eros and enjoyment. Boundaries are a key element to establish delineation, demarcation, borders, and structure in a time when life, love, and work have blurred into one. Follow the link in bio and listen to that session for a deeper look at how to create structure for stress relief and balance.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on August 19, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text:
First dates run the gamut—they can be exciting, exhausting, mysterious, boring, easy, or laborious. What determines the success or disappointment of a first date has less to do with an immediate spark and more to do with creating the right conditions for turning that spark into a lingering flame that leaves us burning to experience more. 

When we’re just beginning to connect with a new person, it’s all about context, education, seduction, and connection. When dating is tough, it can feel like a game that we don’t know how to play. But by focusing on these four areas, we can revel in un-gamified playfulness—that quality of romance, humor, and ease that, when combined with an authentic connection, inspires both parties to go deeper.

To learn more about these first date tips for success, click into the blog through the link in our bio or visit estherperel.com/blog to read on.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Esther Perel on August 17, 2021 tagging @peterattiamd. May be an image of text that says '" Sexuality is a lens. It tells a story of the values the behaviors, and the attitudes towards the body and pleasure, towards power and connection, towards the division of spirit and flesh, or mind and body or all of those things. Esther Perel'.

node.text:
Sexuality is a lens.
When I first studied family therapy and couples therapy, I did so without one formal hour about sexuality. And thought how can that be? In a culture where sexuality is so central to the topic of love and relationship, how can we do couples therapy and not ever talk about it? Something is missing. At the time, the field itself oriented around the idea that sex problems were a result of relationship problems, meaning that fixing the relationship would then fix the problems in the bedroom. My thinking has always been that this is not inaccurate but there is more to the story.
In my conversation with @peterattiamd, we talk about my journey to psychotherapy, the value of our relationships with other’s for one’s sense of wellbeing and how our relationships, sexual and otherwise, can act as a mirror to recognize and heal trauma by reflecting our own maladaptive behaviors. Listen to the full conversation in the link in my bio, and let me know what you think.

node.text:
If I just quit, what will people say? 

Season 2, Episode 1 of "How's Work?" plunges us into the life of the mixed-secrets of a mixed-faith married couple. He’s a physician who can’t open up to his family about wanting out of his profession; she’s a government agent who only recently revealed to him the nature of her profession. Each partner is emotionally drained from the demands of work, with little left over to give each other. Pushed to shove by the pandemic crisis, they now face their own domestic crisis.

In this episode, we decode the stoicism that enables these two to succeed in their jobs — but not in their relationship — and propose a switch towards shared vulnerability and trust to strengthen their connection.
